title: marriage
comment: The union of a man and a woman in a permanent relationship. Though a lifelong monogamous commitment is presented as the ideal, polygamous marriages were occasionally known in OT times and carried the same legal and moral rights and responsibilities. God's relationship with his people is described in terms of the marriage bond.

children.title: marriage, purpose of
children.comment: Marriage is part of God's intention for humanity from creation and forms the basis for the family which is the primary unit of society. Where marriage flourishes it blesses both the couple and the wider community.

children.title: Marriage is part of God's plan for the human race

seealsos.comment: Man and woman are not independent of each other.

children.title: It is to be a committed, exclusive relationship
It is the intended context for raising children
It will not exist in the life to come

seealsos.comment: A woman was expected to be a virgin when she married.

children.title: Falling in love prior to marriage
Husbands are to love their wives
Wives are to submit to their husbands
Celibacy as a calling from God

seealsos.comment: Whilst Paul commends the unmarried state, for those not so called it is no sin to marry

children.title: marriage, customs concerning
children.comment: Marriage between two individuals united their families and involved the whole community. Parents, particularly fathers, took an active part in selecting partners for their children. There was often a long period of betrothal; wedding celebrations were usually elaborate and might last a week or more.

children.title: The choice of a marriage partner
Parents usually chose a suitable partner

seealsos.comment: Occasionally mothers made the wedding arrangements.

primaryrefs.comment: Rebekah is consulted about her proposed marriage to Isaac.

children.title: Daughters were given as a reward
Gifts from the bride's father
children.precomment: Servants given to the bride as a dowry:

children.title: Betrothal followed payment of the bride-price

seealsos.comment: Jacob worked for Laban during his period of betrothal to Rachel.

children.title: A betrothed couple were regarded as husband and wife

secondaryrefs.comment: Unfaithfulness during the period of betrothal is treated as adultery
Divorce is required to break a betrothal.

children.title: Sexual relationships took place only after the wedding

secondaryrefs.comment: Engaged soldiers were to marry before going into battle
Recently married soldiers were exempted from military service for a year.

children.title: The bride wore an elaborate dress and jewellery

primaryrefs.comment: An allegorical description of God dressing Jerusalem as a bride.

children.title: Attendants on the bride and groom

secondaryrefs.comment: Invited guests were called when the feast was ready.
Guests were expected to dress appropriately.

children.title: marriage, restrictions concerning
children.comment: The OT law forbade intermarriage with people who worshipped idols because it threatened the covenant relationship with God and his people. Marriage with close relations was also forbidden. Remarriage is permissible following the death of a spouse and, in certain circumstances, following divorce.

children.title: Intermarriage with foreigners led to idolatry

primaryrefs.comment: Royal marriages to foreigners brought disastrous consequences.

children.title: Parents sought to avoid their children marrying foreigners

seealsos.comment: Abraham seeks a bride for Isaac from among his own people.
Isaac forbids Jacob to marry a Canaanite woman
Samson's parents encourage him to marry an Israelite.

children.title: Marriage to foreigners may be permissible

secondaryrefs.comment: Boaz' marriage to Ruth the Moabitess was acceptable because Ruth embraced the Israelite faith. Restrictions were on the grounds of religion not of race.

children.title: Foreign wives were put aside after the exile
Christians should not leave an unbelieving spouse
Restrictions on marriage to close relatives
Sexual relations with close relatives is forbidden
Examples of marriage to close relatives

secondaryrefs.comment: Abraham was married to his half-sister
Tamar suggests marriage with her half-brother, Amnon.

children.title: The levirate law was instituted to preserve the dead father's name

primaryrefs.comment: Levirate marriage refers to the legal obligation of a brother-in-law to produce heirs for his dead brother by marrying his widow. When there was no brother-in-law responsibility fell to a near relative, also described as a ``kinsman-redeemer''.

children.title: Unwillingness to fulfil the levirate law
Remarriage after divorce may be adultery
Remarriage after divorce permissible in certain circumstances
marriage, between God and his people
children.comment: Marriage is used to describe the relationship between God and Israel in the OT and between Jesus Christ and the church in the NT. Contemplating marriage deepens understanding of God's love for his people; examining God's covenant love for his people similarly enriches an understanding of marriage.

primaryrefs.comment: The covenant at Sinai was seen as a form of marriage.

children.title: The breakdown of God's marriage to Israel
Israel's alienation from God is likened to a divorce

primaryrefs.comment: Israel's unfaithfulness led to a form of divorce between God and his people. This was sometimes identified with the exile.

children.title: The renewal of God's marriage to Israel
God calls his bride to return
Jesus Christ's marriage relationship with the church
Jesus Christ's love as a model for marriage
Jesus Christ is described as a bridegroom

primaryrefs.comment: John the Baptist describes Jesus Christ as the bridegroom and himself as the best man.
